titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Brooklyn glass plate negative collection V1974.015
titlestmt.author: Weatherly Stephan
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-08-21 11:18:52 +0000.

physdesc.extent: in one glass plate negative box, one oversize glass plate negative box, and one folder.

did.abstract: Images in the collection show rural Brooklyn life, street scenes, snowstorms, and the Brooklyn Navy Yard (formally known as the New York Naval Shipyard) in the late 19th century.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Abbot Low Moffat, 1954; Mrs. E. C. Korten, 1976; and William I. Frothingham, date unknown.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: All commercially produced slides are in the public domain. Copyright for all other works will remain in effect for 120 years following the date of creation. Based on the date range of this collection, all items will enter the public domain by 2019. For information on securing rights to publish or reproduce, please see the Brooklyn Historical Society Reproduction Rights Policy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Brooklyn glass plate negative collection contains 18 items dating from circa 1870 to 1899. The negatives are a mix of anonymous creations, reproductions, and original photography by Henry O. Korten. Images in the collection show rural Brooklyn life, street scenes, snowstorms, and the Brooklyn Navy Yard (formally known as the New York Naval Shipyard) in the late 19th century. Locations featured include the neighborhoods of Flatlands, Fort Greene, Clinton Hill, Brooklyn Heights, as well as Prospect Park and the East River waterfront. Two portraits of Native Americans and snowstorm scenes located in the Flushing neighborhood of Queens are also included. Prints from a select number of glass plate negatives are also available.

otherfindaid.head: Other Finding Aids
otherfindaid.p: Item-level description and digital versions of images from the collection are available for searching via the image database in the library.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Brooklyn glass plate negatives collection, V1974.015, Box number, Object ID number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Fully processed to the item level.
